{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} The '''2008–2009 Belgian financial crisis''' is a major financial crisis that hit [[Belgium]] from mid-2008 onwards. Two of the country's largest banks – Fortis and Dexia – started to face severe problems, exacerbated by the financial problems hitting other banks around the world. The value of their stocks plunged. The government managed the situation by bailouts, selling off or nationalizing banks, providing [[bank guarantees]] and extending the [[deposit insurance]]. Eventually Fortis was split into two parts. The Dutch part was nationalized, while the Belgian part was sold to the French bank [[BNP Paribas]]. Dexia group was dismantled, Dexia Bank Belgium was nationalized.
==Context== {{main|Great Recession}} {{See also|Credit crunch}}
The global financial crisis and the credit crunch shocked trust across the board. At the time of [[bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers]] Belgium was in a long simmering [[2007–2011 Belgian political crisis|political crisis]]. The [[Flemish Community|Flemish]] and [[French Community of Belgium|French]] communities were at odds with one another, especially after the electoral gains of the Flemish separatist party [[N-VA]]. The fear of Belgium splitting into two worsened the trust situation. Most of the events took place during the [[Leterme I Government|Leterme I]], [[Van Rompuy I Government|Van Rompuy I]] and [[Leterme II Government]]s. [[Didier Reynders]] was finance minister in all of them. The government was assisted by [[CBFA]] and the [[Court of Audit of Belgium|Court of Audit]].
Historically Belgium has had a high public debt, which in 1993 peaked at 137.8% GDP. In order to be able to join the [[eurozone]] this was greatly reduced to around 100% GDP at the turn of the century. This budgetary discipline was continued after the introduction of the euro, in part to comply with the [[Maastricht Treaty]]. By 2007 the public debt of Belgium had dropped to 84% GDP. The reduced debt increased Belgium's ability to cope with the situation. The government interventions in the financial sector, and deficit spending at a time of economic slowdown has affected the government debt, rising again to 99.6% GDP in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=Public Finances: debt to GDP|url=http://debtagency.be/en_data_public_finances.htm|publisher=Belgian Federal Government|accessdate=30 April 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131217065240/http://debtagency.be/en_data_public_finances.htm|archive-date=17 December 2013|url-status = dead|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
There is a degree of [[Pillarisation#Belgium|pillarisation]] in Belgium. Dexia belonged to the [[Catholic]] pillar, {{Interlanguage link|Ethias|nl}} belongs to the socialist pillar.<ref>{{cite web|last=Van Overtveldt|first=Johan|title=De Ethias-schande|url=http://trends.knack.be/economie/opinie/columns/johan-van-overtveldt/de-ethias-schande/opinie-4000024147390.htm|publisher=Trends.be|accessdate=5 May 2013}}</ref>
==Bank crises==
===Fortis=== {{main|Fortis (finance)}} [[Image:Logo Fortis Delft.jpg|thumb|[[Fortis Bank]] in [[Delft]]]]
Fortis was the largest Belgian bank in early 2008, positioned mainly in the [[Benelux]]. From mid-2008 onwards, the bank began facing severe liquidity problems and its stock value began rapidly declining. The problem was exacerbated by the earlier acquisition of the Dutch bank [[ABN Amro]], which had depleted Fortis' capital.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/07/13/business/fortis.php |title=Fortis chief executive out; chairman now faces shareholder anger |publisher=International Herald Tribune |date=13 July 2008 |accessdate=29 September 2008}}</ref> Since the beginning of 2008, about 3% of the deposits stalled at the bank were withdrawn.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/hotStocksNews/idUKLR15751720080927 |title=FACTBOX-Finances at Belgian-Dutch group Fortis |publisher=Reuters |date=27 September 2008 |accessdate=29 September 2008 | first=Reed | last=Stevenson| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080928151133/http://uk.reuters.com/article/hotStocksNews/idUKLR15751720080927| archivedate= 28 September 2008|url-status = live}}</ref> Belgian and Dutch ministers and financial regulators met each other on 27 September to tackle the crisis.<ref name="BloombergSept28">{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=a3kZTkkP0.uY |title=Belgian, Dutch Regulators Seek to Boost Confidence in Fortis |publisher=Bloomberg.com |date=28 September 2008 |accessdate=29 September 2008}}</ref><ref name="IntHarTribSept27">{{cite web |url=http://www.iht.com/articles/reuters/2008/09/27/business/OUKBS-UK-FORTIS.php |title=Talks on future of Fortis to run into Sunday |publisher=International Harald Tribune |date=27 September 2008 |accessdate=29 September 2008}}</ref>
The following day, Fortis was partially nationalised on 28 September 2008, with [[Belgium]], the [[Netherlands]] and [[Luxembourg]] investing a total of €11.2 billion (US$16.3 billion) in the bank. Belgium will purchase 49% of Fortis's Belgian banking division, with the Netherlands doing the same for the Dutch banking division. Luxembourg has agreed to a loan convertible into a 49% share of Fortis's Luxembourg banking division.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=ahlKDjeO0Lik&refer=home |title=Fortis Gets EU11.2 Billion Rescue From Governments |publisher=Bloomberg |date=29 September 2008 |accessdate=29 September 2008 |first=Martijn |last=van der Starre |author2=Meera Louis}}</ref>
On 3 October the Dutch government purchased the Dutch banking and insurance division of Fortis for €16.8 billion ($23.3 billion),<ref>[http://www.tijd.be/nieuws/ondernemingen_financien/Fortis_wordt_ontmanteld.8085481-433.art Fortis wordt ontmanteld] {{in lang|nl}}</ref> becoming the holder of Fortis Bank Nederland, Fortis Verzekeringen Nederland and Fortis Corporate Insurance, including the part of [[ABN Amro]] held by Fortis.<ref>[http://www.minfin.nl/Actueel/Nieuwsberichten/2008/10/Nederlandse_staat_neemt_Fortis_Bank_Nederland_Fortis_Verzekeringen_Nederland_Fortis_Corporate_Insurance_en_het_Fortis_deel_van_ABN_AMRO_Holding_volledig_over Nederlandse staat neemt Fortis Bank Nederland, Fortis Verzekeringen Nederland, Fortis Corporate Insurance en het Fortis-deel van ABN AMRO Holding volledig over] {{in lang|nl}}</ref> [[BNP Paribas]], a French bank, took a majority stake in Fortis, while Belgian and Luxembourg governments became minority shareholders with blocking power in exchange for shares in BNP Paribas.<ref name="tijd.be">{{cite web|url=http://www.tijd.be/nieuws/ondernemingen_financien/'Overname_Fortis_Bank_door_BNP_rond'.8086128-433.art|title='Overname Fortis Bank door BNP Paribas rond'|publisher=De Tijd|date=5 October 2008|accessdate=5 October 2008|language=nl}}</ref> The deal does not include the main holding company, but does include the insurance and banking subsidiaries, except for Fortis Insurance International.<ref name="tijd.be"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.standaard.be/Artikel/Detail.aspx?artikelId=DMF05102008_045&ref=front|title=BNP Paribas koopt ook Fortis Insurance|publisher=De Standaard|date=5 October 2008|accessdate=5 October 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081008061548/http://www.standaard.be/Artikel/Detail.aspx?artikelId=DMF05102008_045&ref=front| archivedate= 8 October 2008|url-status = live|language=nl}}</ref> Dutch and Belgian shareholders' associations have requested a review of the takeover.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tijd.be/nieuws/economie-financien/Verzet_tegen_overname_van_Fortis_groeit.8087868-600.art|title=Verzet tegen overname van Fortis groeit|publisher=De Tijd|date=8 October 2008|accessdate=8 October 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081009212642/http://www.tijd.be/nieuws/economie-financien/Verzet_tegen_overname_van_Fortis_groeit.8087868-600.art| archivedate= 9 October 2008|url-status = live|language=nl}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2008/10/08/business/EU-Belgium-Fortis.php|title=Fortis shareholders may ask for vote|publisher=International Herald Tribune|date=8 October 2008|accessdate=8 October 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081012074629/http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2008/10/08/business/EU-Belgium-Fortis.php| archivedate= 12 October 2008|url-status = live}}</ref>
Toxic assets were placed in a bad bank called ''[[Royal Park Investments]]''. Thanks in part to good management and multi billion [[euro]] guarantees by the government the holding performed better than expected. In April 2013 it was sold for 2.3 billion euro to the American investment firm ''[[Lone Star Funds|Lone Star]]''. This was good news for public finances (1 billion euro) and the Fortis holding since renamed to [[Ageas]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Government sells Fortis' bad bank to Americans|url=http://www.deredactie.be/permalink/1.1614837|publisher=vrtnieuws|accessdate=27 April 2013|date=27 April 2013|language=nl}}</ref>
===Dexia=== {{main|Dexia}} [[Image:Dexia Bank wordt Belfius.jpg|thumb|Window ad announcing the name change of [[Dexia|Dexia Bank Belgium]]]]
On 30 September 2008 the Belgian, French and Luxembourg governments said they would put in €6.4bn to keep Dexia afloat.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/7643638.stm |title=Second Belgian bank gets bail-out |publisher=BBC News |date=30 September 2008 |accessdate=30 September 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081002052613/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/7643638.stm| archivedate=2 October 2008|url-status = live}}</ref>
The problems at Dexia stem in part from a multi-billion loan to troubled German bank [[Depfa]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.standaard.be/Artikel/Detail.aspx?artikelId=DMF05102008_017|title=Regering moet twee banken redden|publisher=De Standaard|date=5 October 2008|accessdate=5 October 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081006203056/http://www.standaard.be/Artikel/Detail.aspx?artikelId=DMF05102008_017| archivedate= 6 October 2008|url-status = live}}</ref> and potential losses at its US subsidiary FSA. The Dexia board stated on 5 October 2008 that the capital addition by the governments would put it in a position in which it could deal with deteriorating market conditions, and that the credit risks associated with [[Hypo Real Estate]] and Depfa are only limited.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tijd.be/nieuws/ondernemingen_financien/'Dexia_kan_hoofd_bieden_aan_verslechterende_marktomstandigheden'_.8086121-433.art|title='Dexia kan hoofd bieden aan verslechterende marktomstandigheden'|publisher=De Tijd|date=5 October 2008|accessdate=5 October 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dexia.com/docs/2008/2008_news/20081005_bd_uk.pdf|format=PDF|title=5 October 2008 press release – Board of Directors|publisher=Dexia|date=5 October 2008|accessdate=5 October 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081029172316/http://www.dexia.com/docs/2008/2008_news/20081005_bd_uk.pdf| archivedate= 29 October 2008|url-status = dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dexia.com/e/news/press-release-desc.php?id=4110&p=0|title=5 October 2008 press release – Dexia – Hypo Real Estate (HRE)|publisher=Dexia|date=5 October 2008|accessdate=5 October 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081007221310/http://www.dexia.com/e/news/press-release-desc.php?id=4110&p=0| archivedate= 7 October 2008|url-status = dead}}</ref>
Market conditioned worsened over the following years, generating losses. On the sale of FSA, due to the fall of Lehman brother and Icelandic banks and finally due to a large exposure to the [[Greek government-debt crisis]].<ref name="Bad Bank">{{cite web | url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-10-04/dexia-to-set-up-bad-bank-with-guarantees-from-france-belgium.html | title=Dexia to Set Up 'Bad Bank' With Guarantees From France, Belgium | accessdate=5 October 2011}}</ref>
Eventually, in October 2011, the group was dismantled Dexia bank Belgium was bought by the Belgian federal government for 4 billion euro and changed its name to [[Belfius]]. Other healthy components were also sold off and the toxic assets remained in the Dexia Holding.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970203633104576620720705508498 | title=France, Belgium Reach Pact on Ailing Dexia | accessdate=10 October 2011 | work=The Wall Street Journal | first=Matthew | last=Dalton | date=10 October 2011}}</ref><ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-10-10/belgium-paying-eu4-billion-for-dexia-belgian-unit-reynders-says.html Belgium Paying EU4 Billion for Dexia Belgian Unit, Reynders Says]. Bloomberg. Retrieved on 11 October 2011.</ref> Dexia holding is Europe's largest [[bad bank]].<ref>{{cite news|title=EU zet licht op groen voor vers kapitaal Dexia|url=http://www.deredactie.be/permalink/1.1514275|accessdate=11 January 2013|newspaper=vrtnieuws|date=28 December 2012}}</ref> Operating with the help of [[bank guarantees]] of the Belgian and French governments Dexia holding is tasked to minimize the losses on its [[toxic assets]]. The holding is still generating large losses, which led Belgium and France to inject another €5.5 billion in 2012.<ref>{{cite news|title=België en Frankrijk pompen 5,5 miljard euro in Dexia|url=http://www.deredactie.be/permalink/1.1476548|accessdate=11 January 2013|newspaper=vrtnieuws|date=8 November 2012}}</ref>
===Dexia share holders===
* '''Ethias''' (previously OMOB/SMAP) is an insurance group and is also known for being a partner in the [[Ethias Arena]] and various sport sponsorships. Ethias held a 5% share in Dexia. In exchange for cooperation during the Dexia crisis the federal government agreed to extend the deposit insurance to also cover so called ''TAK 21'' products. These include individual saving accounts by an insurance company rather than a bank. Although all TAK 21 products were covered it was mainly intended to protect Ethias' popular ''FIRST accounts''. :When Dexia's share had collapsed, liquidity problems ensued. The group was forced to raise its capital and petitioned the federal and regional governments which were already among its largest shareholders.<ref>{{cite news|title=Kapitaalverhoging Ethias is bijna rond|url=http://www.deredactie.be/permalink/1.399673|accessdate=9 January 2013|newspaper=vrtniews|date=27 October 2008}}</ref> The federal, Flemish and Walloon governments each invested 500 million euro for a total of 1.5 billion. The European Commission approved the bailout but demanded that it shed several activities including the ''FIRST accounts''. Overall the group is to downsize 38%.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ethias moet 38 procent afslanken|url=http://www.deredactie.be/permalink/1.784237|accessdate=9 January 2013|newspaper=vrtnieuws|date=20 May 2010}}</ref> :In 2011 there was little interest in bonds issued by Ethias the governments were again petitioned. They agreed to buy into the bonds for a total of 180 million euro.<ref>{{cite news|title=Overheden springen Ethias bij|url=http://www.deredactie.be/permalink/1.1185901|accessdate=9 January 2013|newspaper=vrtnieuws|date=29 December 2011}}</ref> :Early 2013 the [[holding company]] Vitrufin (previously Ethias Finance nv) announced it had sold all of its Dexia shares. Thereby eliminating the groups exposure to Dexia.<ref>{{cite news|title=Vitrufin (Ethias) doet volledige participatie in Dexia van de hand|url=http://www.standaard.be/artikel/detail.aspx?artikelid=DMF20130110_00428750|accessdate=11 January 2013|newspaper=De Standaard|date=10 January 2013}}</ref>
* '''Arco''' the financial leg of the [[Confederation of Christian Trade Unions]] was [[liquidated]]. The government however does intend to compensate the nearly 800,000 participants in '''Arcopar''', a related [[cooperative]]. Motivating its decision by stating that many were sold ''Arcopar shares'' under the pretext of a safe savings instrument rather than a speculative stock. This has led to legal action by investors who find that this violates the [[Equality before the law|equality principle]]. In March 2013 the [[Council of State (Belgium)|Council of State]] ruled largely against the investors, the question of equality and discrimination was passed on to the [[Constitutional Court of Belgium]]. Which is yet to make a decision.<ref>{{cite news|title=Council of state does not nullify the arco compensation|url=http://www.deredactie.be/permalink/1.1584367|accessdate=29 April 2013|newspaper=vrtniuews|date=25 March 2013|language=nl}}</ref> * '''Gemeentelijke Holding''' was a holding company of which all Belgian [[Municipalities of Belgium|municipalities]] and [[Provinces of Belgium|provinces]] were stake holders. The majority of its funds were invested in Dexia. After the nationalization it was liquidated.<ref>{{cite news|title=Akkoord over vereffening Gemeentelijke Holding|url=http://www.demorgen.be/dm/nl/996/Economie/article/detail/1337699/2011/10/22/Akkoord-over-vereffening-Gemeentelijke-Holding.dhtml|accessdate=29 April 2013|newspaper=De Morgen|date=22 October 2011|language=nl}}</ref>
===KBC=== {{main|KBC Bank}}
Since the beginning of October 2008, the price of KBC shares had dropped by more than half. The turbulence on the international financial markets and the skewed domestic situation after the government bail-out of its two largest competitors had increased the pressure. On Saturday 25 October, KBC was reported to be in talks with the Belgian government, hoping to obtain a €3.5 billion cash injection.<ref>{{cite news|title=KBC mikt op extra buffer van 3,5 miljard euro|url=http://www.standaard.be/cnt/DMF25102008_003?kanaalid=42|accessdate=28 April 2013|newspaper=De Standaard|date=25 October 2008|language=nl}}</ref> The company, which is also active in Central Europe, fears the harm of the financial woes hitting that region. The deal was approved.<ref>{{cite news|title=Kapitaalinjectie KBC goedgekeurd, bank schrapt dividend|url=http://www.gva.be/nieuws/economie/kapitaalinjectie-kbc-goedgekeurd-bank-schrapt-dividend.aspx|accessdate=27 April 2013|newspaper=Het Laatste Nieuws|date=26 October 2008|language=nl}}</ref> The extra cash was used to increase its risk buffer.
Because KBC is seen by the Walloons as a mainly Flemish bank, the federal government was unwilling to participate in a second intervention. In January 2009, the Flemish government stepped in KBC for €2 billion. In addition KBC was allowed to issue bonds to the Flemish government for up to 1.5 billion euro.<ref>{{cite news|title=Vlaamse regering pompt twee miljard in KBC|url=http://www.standaard.be/cnt/DMF22012009_007|accessdate=28 April 2013|newspaper=De Standaard|date=22 January 2009|language=nl}}</ref>
When the credit rating of [[MBIA]] an American insurer, which specializes in bond insuring, was downgraded to junk this decreased the value of KBC's risky assets. A third agreement was made. Mid-May 2009 the federal government announced it will offer bank guarantees for up to 2 billion euro.<ref>{{cite news|title=KBC's MBIA Losses|url=https://www.forbes.com/2009/05/14/kbc-mbia-exposure-markets-equity-banks.html|accessdate=28 April 2013|newspaper=forbes|date=14 May 2009}}</ref>
In 2012 KBC made a profit of 612 million euro. By the end of that year, and ahead of schedule, KBC had paid back all of the 3.5 billion euro of support from the federal government. It also plans to pay back the support from the Flemish government at an accelerated pace, starting with 1.17 billion in 2013.<ref>{{cite news|title=KBC betaalt overheid deze maand 3 miljard euro terug|url=http://www.hln.be/hln/nl/942/Economie/article/detail/1546416/2012/12/10/KBC-betaalt-overheid-deze-maand-3-miljard-euro-terug.dhtml|accessdate=27 April 2013|newspaper=Het Laatste Nieuws|date=10 December 2012|language=nl}}</ref>
==Government reaction== Besides the bail-outs of both Fortis and Dexia, the government also guaranteed all bank savings up to €20,000. This limit was later raised to €100,000.<ref>{{cite news|title=België beschermt spaarder tot 100.000 euro|url=http://www.deredactie.be/permalink/1.393949|accessdate=28 April 2013|newspaper=vrtnieuws|date=7 October 2008|language=nl}}</ref> On Saturday 11 October, the government announced that all banks, including the smaller ones, could obtain a similar guarantee on the condition that they are solvent and pay a fee.<ref>{{cite news|title=Leningen van alle banken nu gegarandeerd|url=http://www.deredactie.be/permalink/1.395945|accessdate=28 April 2013|newspaper=vrtnieuws|date=11 October 2008|language=nl}}</ref>
The government also negotiated in deals to protect the savings of the 16,000 Belgian customers of the Icelandic [[Kaupthing Bank]] whose money was locked up for months following the [[2008–2011 Icelandic financial crisis|crisis in Iceland]]. They belonged to the subsidiary Kaupthing Bank Luxembourg. Which was finally taken over by ''Blackfish Capital'' the Belgian accounts were taken over by [[Crelan]]. Which later also took over ''Centea'' part of the activities KBC had to shed from the [[European Commission]] as compensation for the government support.<ref>{{cite news|title=Centea is nu van Landbouwkrediet|url=http://deredactie.be/cm/vrtnieuws/economie/1.1056444|accessdate=30 April 2013|newspaper=vrtnieuws|date=1 June 2011|language=nl}}</ref>
When in late 2011 the interest rates on Belgian government bonds rose to irrational heights the government asked for support from the population and promoted the ''staatsbon''. The ''staatsbon'' is a government bond that can be easily purchased at banks without any knowledge of the stock exchange. The long term rates on the international markets briefly spiked above 5.5%. The consumer purchasable bonds offered gross interests rates of 3.5%, 4%, 4.2% depending on the runtime of 3, 5 or 8 years. This was twice that of a standard savings account.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hoeveel levert de staatsbon meer op dan het spaarboekje?|url=http://www.hln.be/hln/nl/943/Consument/article/detail/1357281/2011/12/02/Hoeveel-levert-de-staatsbon-meer-op-dan-het-spaarboekje.dhtml|accessdate=29 April 2013|newspaper=Het Laatste Nieuws|date=2 December 2011|language=nl}}</ref> The attractive rate, and the promotion resulted in a success. This way the government managed to borrow 5.68 billion euro below market rates.<ref>{{cite news|title=Staatsbons brengen 5,68 miljard euro op|url=http://www.deredactie.be/permalink/1.1170087|accessdate=29 April 2013|newspaper=vrtnieuws|date=5 December 2012}}</ref> Colloquially this iteration of the ''staatsbon'' is referred to as the Leterme-staatsbon after then Prime minister [[Yves Leterme]]. Shortly after the measure, and with a new government finally being formed the interest rates started to drop. Early 2013 even to the lowest level they had been since the introduction of the euro(below 2%). Allowing them to be resold at a profit.<ref>{{cite news|title=Staatsbon-Leterme gaat vlot van de hand|url=http://www.hln.be/hln/nl/943/Consument/article/detail/1539145/2012/11/24/Staatsbon-Leterme-gaat-vlot-van-de-hand.dhtml|accessdate=29 April 2013|newspaper=Het Laatste Nieuws|date=24 November 2012|language=nl}}</ref>
==Stock market reaction== [[File:BEL20-bankbailout.png|thumb|[[BEL-20]] reaction]] The [[BEL-20]] stock index lost more than 20% of its value during the week of 6–10 October, making it the largest weekly decline in the stock index' history.<ref>{{cite web|title=BEL20 Historical data|url=http://stooq.com/q/d/?s=^bel20&c=0&d1=19910102&d2=20090101&i=w|publisher=stooq.com|accessdate=30 April 2013}}</ref> At the time Fortis, Dexia and KBC stocks made up 29.78% of the weighted index.
